bibl.title: Letter from Harold Leidelin to Henry Rose Carter, May 18, 1915

div1.p: Leidelin thanks Carter for a reprint on impounded waters and malaria. He expresses disappointment about the lack of support by others for his work.

div1.head: Letter from Harold Leidelin to Henry Rose Carter, May 18, 1915
div1.opener:
THE INCORPORATED
LIVERPOOL SCHOOL OF TROPICAL MEDICINE.
____________
Telephone 2402 Royal,
YELLOW FEVER BUREAU,
UNIVERSITY OF LIVERPOOL.
May 18th 1915
Dear Dr. Carter,
div1.p:
Immediately on receipt of your letter of April 1st,
for which I thank you heartily, I sent you all the reprints that I
could lay hand on. I trust you have received them. Yesterday I received
a reprint from your father of his paper on impounded water and malaria;
I have read it with great interest, and I beg you to thank your father
for it and to give him my sincere regards. I hope he is now quite well.

You are quite right in saying that no one has undertaken to xxxxx
repeat my work with an open mind. Even those who have confirmed my
work started in the belief that I was wrong. Macfie, Connal, and Johnston
who, working in West Africa, have confirmed my results, have all told
me that they had been filled with so much talking against me that they
were convinced of the non-existence of the Paraplasma, until they found
it themselves. Personally, I have not the slightest doubt that my
results will come to stand, but it may take a long time, and it appears
that I shall have no opportunity of continuing my work on this problem.
My work here is soon coming to an end, and I have been unable to
obtain any other appointment which put me in a position to take up
similar investigations. Considering the state of affairs in Mexico,
you will understand that it isn out of the question to return to my
previous or to a similar position there. I was therefore particularly
glad to see that you take an interest in the matter, and I hope that
you and your Colleagues in the Service will be successful in following
2
up the life cycle of the parasite, especially the evolution in the
mosquito - where I failed. Connal, who is a very good man indeed, has
told me that he is not going to rest until he has done all in his
power to xxxxxx settle the question one way or the other, but the
problem is, of course, public property, and I daresay that you have both
the men and the means.

If I live long enough I shall perhaps have the satisfaction
of seeing the diagnosis of yellow fever on a firm basis by the routine
demonstration of the P.flavigenum, and possibly a vaccine prophylaxis
in full swing. I shall always be glad to discuss details with you, if
you care to write to me, but what suggestions I might have to make
are, I believe, embodied in my papers, of which those dealing with
work in West Africa have been delayed, but will soon appear. I may
not have a copy to send you, as the Colonial Office Commission are
xxxxxxxx issuing these volumes, though in connection with our Bureau,
but several of your libraries will, of course, receive copies.

In the meantime I am a bit sick at the way that my work has been
attacked. You know Agramonte's way, and you have no doubt seen others
using about the same style of “criticism”. What can one do when two
authors assert that the scientific world is against me whilst the truth
is that those two have been working up an opinion, doing all the writing
themselves, signed or anonymously, the same two men in four Journals.

I shall probably go back to Denmark when my time is up here, but
I do not know for certain yet. Before that I am getting ready the last
number of the Bulletin which we have been preparing for some time, but
the West African Reports have taken a lot of time and must be out first.
Be sure to send me all that you write.

Kindest regards also to Dr. James and others whom I had the pleasure of meeting
at the Canal Zone.
